transcription.text: Hi, I'm Jeremy, co-founder of Funfair.
And we've spent the last 18 months
building a platform that uses state channels, which is now
live on Mainnet and has been for about a month.
So realistically, I'm so I'm going to talk to you today
about our experiences that we've learned over the last 18
months doing this.
So what is Funfair?
So Funfair is a casino platform, which
allows a wide variety of games to be run in real time.
But the gameplay is backed on the chain using state channels,
as we will be talking about today.
So I'm going to blast through this.
We have a fairly specific sort of formal state channels
that we've developed for our application
rather than developing something massively generalized.
So we have a two-party bidirectional channel.
And we support a fully-generic state machine.
So we will support state machines that pretty much
can do anything.
As long as it can be expressed in a contract pool,
there can be executed on the chain.
And I'm going to talk about that in some detail.
We also provide an integrated RNG into this,
which is a form of a complex commit reveal scheme using hashes.
It's deterministic but not predictable.
And we feed essentially one random number
into every state transition that's
available for the state machines to use.
It's optimized for our use for casino games.
Unlike a lot of the examples that people talk about when
they have chess people taking one move and then another move
and then another move.
We advance the action-- the advance
the state with an action from both players at the same time.
So it's more like rock-paper-scissors
where both people are doing this at the same time.
And we combine that together with a random number
to produce the next state in the sequence.
This actually makes writing the state machines themselves
a lot simpler, as there's only really one function
to advance the state.
But it does make dispute resolution quite a bit harder.
So all of our disputes, which come from various reasons,
timeouts, network, disk, network,
network problems, incorrect state transitions,
just general software problems, we
reduce to a single statement, which
is that the other party is not following the protocol
of the state channel.
And state channels, it's really important
to understand are a protocol.
They are a series of statements by which the state is advanced.
Those are the rules that need to be followed.
So if that actually happens, then the person with the claimant
makes a claim on chain using the previous cosine state
that both parties have agreed to,
and what they think the next one should be.
And the contract validates that that's
a valid state transition.
And if that is correct, then we raise a dispute.
And then the counterparty can do a number of things.
They can go, OK, that was a problem, right.
I better do something about this.
And they can provide the next state transition.
And if that's done and validated on chain,
then we have a great side effect,
which means that we can actually carry on from that point
off chain and complete the contract.
This is a really, really powerful thing.
The counterparty can say no dispute as in, well,
yeah, probably that's my fault.
And can we just close the channel where we are?
The counterparty can do nothing if the laptop is blown up,

The channel times out, and the claim out
can close the channel subsequently

there's penalties or not, whether or not

with an earlier state.
We think that is malicious, especially
because we've been treating the casino games here.
So we treat that as a penalty to the person that
put the earlier state on the chain because of the variance.

Right, quick one on liveness.
So state channels require participants to be live.
As in, you have to always be there to respond to the messages
to advance the state.
If you go away, the channel can't advance.
So it's fairly obvious in itself.
But if you go away, how long do you
go away for before you do something about it?
If you just turn your computer off and walk away,
you have violated the protocol of a state channel.
So the longer the channel is expected to last,
the longer your timeouts need to be.
I think that's probably self-explanatory.
But timeouts need to be short or long.
There's a kind of period in the middle
where it makes no sense for the timeouts to be.
So what situations are you trying to cover?
If users just close this laptop and walk away, well,
then you can probably close the channel fairly quickly.
But if it's important enough, and there's enough value

or they've gone on holiday and they've forgotten about it,
the risk to them of losing all of their funds,
you have to really understand and think

to choose for your timeouts.
Right, automated blockchain transactions I need to crack on.

So you need to make very careful assumptions about gas price
